entry.title: Future Proof Microsoft Outlook Integration for SAP Sales Cloud with Microsoft Graph
entry.content:
To keep your sales team operating at peak efficiency, the tools they use must be reliable and future-proof. That's why we made migrating your SAP Sales Cloud's Server-Side Groupware Integration to leverage modern Microsoft Graph APIs a simple but important step to take. This isn't just about maintaining continuity; it's about enhancing security, improving reliability, and aligning with Microsoft's direction. Let's explore how this straightforward update can protect your sales operations from disruption.

The 5-Step Migration Process from EWS to Graph API

Now for the practical part. The good news is that we have made this migration process manageable. The core strategy isn't about changing your existing setup in-place, but rather creating a new, correctly configured Organization within Groupware and then moving your users into it. This approach minimizes risk and ensures a clean, controlled transition. Here is the step-by-step process to migrate your users, just like our official documentation describes it:

Step 1: Log in and Navigate to Organizations

First, log in to your SAP Sales Cloud V2 system with administrative privileges. From the main dashboard, navigate to the Groupware settings by going to:

Settings > Groupware > Organizations

This is the central hub where you manage how different groups of users connect to their email servers.

Step 2: Create a New Organization

Click to create a new organization. This will serve as the new home for all users connecting via the Microsoft Graph API. Give it a clear, descriptive name (e.g., "Microsoft Graph Users" or "M365 Graph Sync") to avoid confusion, and then save it.

Step 3: Configure the Mailbox for Graph API

This is the most crucial step. Select the new organization you just created. Within its settings, find the Email Configuration tab. Here, you must change the Mailbox Access Type from the default or EWS setting to the required option for Microsoft Graph APIs. This tells SAP Sales Cloud to use the modern authentication and API methods for this specific organization.

Step 4: Move Users to the New Organization

With your new Graph API-enabled organization ready, it's time to move the users over from the old EWS-based organization. SAP provides two flexible methods for this:

  • Bulk Move: Navigate to the main Users List in the Groupware section. From here, you can select multiple (or all) users at once and move them to the new organization. This is the most efficient method for migrating everyone.

  • Individual Move: If you prefer a phased rollout or need to move specific users one by one, you can go into each user's User Details Page and reassign them to the new organization individually.

Step 5: Verify and Decommission

Once users have been moved, their groupware sync will begin using the new Microsoft Graph API connection. It is highly recommended to test with a pilot user or group to confirm that emails, appointments, and contacts are synchronizing correctly. After you have successfully migrated all users and confirmed functionality, you can safely decommission the old EWS-based organization to complete the process.

Finalizing the Switch: The Key to Unlocking the Benefits

By following these steps, you're not just performing a technical update; you're actively future-proofing your sales team's most critical integration. However, remember there is one final, user-driven step to lock in these benefits. The migration is only finalized once each user re-authenticates their connection.

After being moved to the new organization, each user must navigate to Groupware User Settings > My Sync Status > Email Configuration and update their settings. This action will trigger a one-time consent request from Microsoft. Once they grant consent, their synchronization will officially and permanently switch to the more secure, reliable, and modern Microsoft Graph API. This final handshake ensures every member of your team is transitioned smoothly, securing your data flow and delivering the seamless operational continuity that is vital for sales success.

entry.title: General Task List Approval Process
entry.content:
Hello,

I need help with a specific topic. A customer wants to implement an approval process for general task lists.

They do not want the process to proceed when a general task list is created or changed without manager approval.

The idea is to create a custom Z-table to store the information temporarily, and once approval is given, use the appropriate BAPI — either EAM_TASKLIST_CREATE or EAM_TASKLIST_CHANGE depending on the task — to proceed with the process in alignment with the approval flow.

However, my main issue is that some of these general task lists are linked to calibrations, and I couldn’t find a suitable BAPI for this part. Could you help me with this? Is there any BAPI available to handle MIC (Master Inspection Characteristic) linkage for Type A general task lists?

I considered using a BDC, but I’m not sure if a BAPI and BDC can be executed in sequence reliably. Also, this is not a one-time upload or update — it’s an ongoing process. That’s why I don’t think BDC would be an effective solution, as it can easily fail if the data deviates even slightly from the expected format.

I would appreciate your support.

Best Regard

entry.title: Re: Digital Signature reporting in SolDoc
entry.content:
There is no such report and no new development for that. Since solution manager will reach end of mainstream maintenance in 2027. (See SAPnote:3255311) In line with this decision, we are focusing on maintaining the stability and reliability of the current version rather than introducing new features.

Maybe you can go to the List View and display only Documents and filter with the status after the first signature was done and the document type. At least in that way you can see a list of the documents which need to be signed, although you cannot see if one specific person has to sign.

entry.title: SAP Build Process Automation クラウド上でループ処理を導入する方法について
entry.content:
各位
お疲れ様です。
件名に記載した内容になるのですが、ご存じの方がいらっしゃいましたら是非ご教授ください。
現在SAP Build Process Automationの開発を行っております。
その中で、「自動プロセス」を活用して特定のリストをループ処理する仕組みの実装を試みています。
実際に「For Each」を利用したループ処理を導入した際に「デスクトップエージェント」が必要と表示されました。
今回実装したい内容として、デスクトップエージェントの導入は検討しておらず、
例えば特定の時間になったら自動で「For Each」等を使用したループ処理を実行させたいと考えております。

エラー文言：
システムのヘルスチェックで問題が発生しました。
DesktopAgentに到達できませんでした。
ブラウザ拡張が有効化されており、最新であることを確認し、次にページをリフレッシュしてください。

そこで以下の3点についてご教授いただけないでしょうか？
１．SAP Build Process Automationの自動化プロセスを利用する場合、デスクトップエージェントの導入は必須でしょうか。
２．特にデスクトップアプリを操作しない / 利用しない自動化の場合も、デスクトップエージェントが必要でしょうか？
３．SAP Build Process Automationの自動化プロセスをクラウド上でのみ動作させる手法はございますでしょうか？

今発生している問題点については一部添付ファイルを添付させていただきます。
なにとぞご協力よろしくお願いいたします。

entry.title: Withholding tax for customer invoice in Italy #COE#RFL01
entry.content:
Hello,

I work for an Italian company that already have withholding tax for supplier invoice. But recently they have been asking to manage withholding for customer invoices.

I checked the SCCUI but I didn’t have access to SCCUI 104408 who make links between a condition type and the withholding type.

After checking document “SSCUI_List_EN_XX.xlsm”, I can see that SCCUI 104408 is not available for Italy.

So, I deduce that SAP is not compliant with withholding tax for customer invoice in Italy.

But as it is a legal obligation, I think there are some workarounds.

Have you some information or feedback about that?

Yours sincerely,

Teddy.

#COE#RFL01
